While some organizations may attempt to downplay the risks, the reality is that 5G technology introduces new frequencies and higher energy levels, particularly in the millimeter wave range, which have not been thoroughly studied in the context of long-term human exposure.

One of the most concerning aspects of 5G is its use of higher-frequency radio waves, which are absorbed more rapidly by the human body, particularly the skin and eyes. This can lead to increased thermal effects and potential damage to tissues. Studies have shown that even non-thermal effects—biological changes that occur at exposure levels below those that cause heating—can have harmful impacts. These include DNA damage, oxidative stress, and disruption of cellular processes.

There are also documented cases of people experiencing symptoms such as headaches, fatigue, dizziness, and sleep disturbances in areas with high 5G deployment. These symptoms are consistent with electrohypersensitivity, a condition increasingly recognized in the medical literature. In several countries, public health authorities have issued warnings or called for a moratorium on 5G expansion due to the potential risks.

The fact is, 5G is being rolled out at an unprecedented speed without sufficient long-term safety testing. Given the known biological effects of electromagnetic radiation and the new variables introduced by 5G technology, it is reasonable and prudent to take these health concerns seriously.
